Package edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.hg

Class MaxGraph

java.lang.Object
edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.hg.HeuristicGraph
edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.hg.MaxGraph
All Implemented Interfaces:
Serializable
public class MaxGraph extends HeuristicGraph
A max graph is a heuristic graph where the cost of a conjunction is defined to be the maximum cost of and of its conjuncts. Costs in a max graph are meant to approximate the lowest cost an expression can have. A max graph should never overestimate. A max graph imitates Blum and Furst's plan graph data structure (without mutexes) and can be used to calculate things like Hoffmann's Fast Forward heuristic.

Specifically:

  • The cost of a clause node being true is cost of its highest cost precondition.
  • The cost of a precondition node being true is higher of the costs of the values for the left and right sides that make its comparison true.
  • The cost of an arithmetic node having a value is the higher of the costs of the values for the left and right sides of the expression that cause the arithmetic expression to have that value.
  • The cost of a utility node having a value is the higher of the cost of the branch of the utility expression having that value and the cost of that goal node's condition.
  • The cost of an effect node is the higher of the cost of its condition and the lowest cost of any of the events that have that effect.
  • The cost of an effect node assigning a value to its fluent is the higher of the cost of the effect node and the cost of that value.
By default, numeric ranges in a max graph are modeled by infinite spans.
Author:
Stephen G. Ware
